patient_information: A 55-year-old female from Vietnam. She is a pig farmer and works as a butcher selling pork and chicken. She has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension, on treatment for 4 years.
chief_complaint: Fever, headache, and vomiting for 1 day, followed by confusion on the second day of illness.
history_of_present_illness: The patient presented to a hospital in rural Vietnam with a 1-day history of fever, headache, and vomiting. Initial blood film was negative for malaria, and she was treated with fluids and paracetamol. On the second day of illness, she developed confusion and was referred to a hospital in Ho Chi Minh City for further investigation.
exposure_and_epidemiology: From rural Vietnam. She raises pigs on her smallholding and works as a butcher in a local market selling pork and chicken. Malaria, enteric fever, and dengue fever are endemic in rural Vietnam/South-east Asia. Streptococcus suis is the commonest identified cause of acute bacterial meningitis in adults in Vietnam, linked to contact with pigs and raw pork.
vitals: Fever (38.5°C or 101.3°F), tachycardia (124 bpm), hypotension (85/60 mmHg), tachypnoea (32 breaths per minute), and hypoxia (O2 saturation 86% on ambient air).
physical_exam: Confused with a Glasgow Coma Score of 12/15 (E3 M5 V4). Neck stiffness and photophobia were present. No focal neurological signs. A diffuse petechial rash was noted over her trunk, and marked purpuric non-blanching lesions on her left leg. The rest of her examination was unremarkable.
labs_and_diagnostics: Initial blood film: negative for malaria. On admission: WBC 10.25 x 10^9/L, % Neutrophils 86.5, Haemoglobin 11.8 g/dL, Platelets 56 x 10^9/L, Creatinine 0.86 mg/dL, Blood urea nitrogen 7 mg/dL, Na+ 137 mmol/l, K+ 3.2 mmol/l, Random blood glucose 15.4 mmol/L, HbA1c 8.5%, Lactate 11.2 mmol/L. Non-contrast-enhanced CT scan of the brain: unremarkable. Electrocardiogram: sinus tachycardia, otherwise normal. Chest x-ray: unremarkable. Lumbar puncture: turbid CSF with 2870 cells/μL (92% neutrophils), protein 541.16 mg/dL, CSF glucose 2.44 mmol/l. Simultaneous blood glucose: 19 mmol/L, CSF/serum glucose ratio 0.12. Gram stain: Gram-positive coccus in short chains. Negative India ink, mycobacterial GeneXpert, and Herpes simplex virus PCR. Repeat malaria film and rapid diagnostic tests were negative. Blood and CSF cultures (5 days later): grew S. suis, sensitive to penicillin and ceftriaxone.
differential_diagnosis: Severe malaria, Enteric fever, Dengue fever, Melioidosis, Acute bacterial meningitis (including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus suis), Tuberculous meningitis, Cryptococcal meningitis.
management_and_clinical_course: Initially treated with fluids and paracetamol. Subsequently received empirical treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone and vancomycin, and supportive treatment including intravenous fluids. Dexamethasone was administered for the first 4 days. The patient received 12 days of antibiotic therapy. She responded to treatment but had residual bilateral hearing impairment.
